results.title: The French doors
results.creator_credit: Sam Brunette, Liz Garneau and Steve Ayson
results.brief_description: A man is renovating his home and adds a set of French doors to the house. When he wakes the next morning the world has taken a dramatic turn into the unknown.

results.title: 15' Zondergrond = 15' Metromania = 15 Metromania
results.creator_credit: Bert Hamelinck, Karl Huysmans and Bart Van den Bempt
results.brief_description: Bernd is the new security guard at the Metro underground. Just as he relaxes into the position, a stern boss dictates some impossible rules and young Bernd’s day goes from bad to worse. Drawing on the aesthetic of the surveillance industry, director Bart Van den Bempt parallels surveillance type images alongside the running plot with split screens. As Bernd, infatuation by a young woman, tracks her movements using the security cameras, we the audience tour the process of security camera surveillance. The film style and structure become bound to the processes of surveillance, whilst the process of surveillance informs the film structure (specifically the narrative and the editing style).

results.title: Substantial shadows
results.brief_description: An elegant, silent meditation on different light forms as they emerge from and transform different obscure, shadowy environments. A miner’s torch flickers across the walls of a cave, a candle flame flickers in a shadow dance, a bonfire blazes in the darkness, a trail of artificial lights illuminate a kitsch architectural structure. Creating a montage that takes its rhythms from the waxing and waning motions of the different light sources Austrian artist Lisl Ponger proposes a playful and poetic contemplation of light and shadow and their qualities when captured as cinematic images.

results.title: The Diary of Mr. N: 1938-1967
results.brief_description:
This film opens in the late thirties with the love affair and marriage of Mr N, a munitions engineer, to Ilona, a secretary at his factory. Over the next thirty years we see their lives unfold, as this energetic and outwards-looking man records his work, his leisure, and the violent political upheavals of his country.

Like an epic novel, Mr N’s film diary has a huge cast of characters from all strata of society, a wide range of settings - both urban and rural, and every year or so, a new baby born to Ilona.

Mr N films prolifically and without self-consciousness, documenting what intrigues, interests and impresses him. His family survives the 1944 seige of Budapest by spending winter in an air raid shelter; in ‘53 he films several of his eight children marching in a May Day rally; in ‘56 a crowd destroying a statue of Stalin; in ‘67 Ilona lying on a deck chair, reading a glamour magazine. An incredible record of personal stability through traumatic times.

results.title: Father and his three sons: the Bartos family
results.brief_description:
Zoltan Bartos, an amateur filmmaker and composer of popular dance music made home movies between the end of the 1920s and the middle of the 1950s.

The Bartos family present themselves in a semi-formal way to Zoltan’s camera; children dance in national costume, young wives smile and wave, relatives act out slapstick routines in imitation of ‘the movies’ and solemn groups pay their respects at the cemetary. Holiday destinations, new cars, business ventures and political rallies are all recorded as significant reference points in the life and times of the family.

Peter Forgacs gently manipulates the footage, playing with the speed and order of events, adding sound effects, voice over and the evocative music of Tibor Szemzo. The resulting film focuses our attention on both the small intimacies and larger tragedies of the family which are implied but not directly expressed in the original sequences. A couple dancing is slowed down to the point of intense romantic reverie; a woman ages before our eyes, leaving the family via divorce, never to be seen again.

The men of the family, Zoltan, his father and two brothers are captured in freeze-frame portraits, as we learn of their various fates during and after the second world war. Oversize portraits of Lenin and Stalin are carried through the streets; a fascinating dialogue between private and public history.

results.title: Either-or
results.brief_description: Writes Forgacs: “Sensual and unknowing - perhaps this is the best metaphor to characterise the film. The families find protection from the terrors of socialism in the private sphere and the ancient human dramas, muffled amorous dependencies. The hardly visible yet palpable relationships are grasped by the viewer’s eyes…. In civil life, everything goes on even if the spontaneous actors do not see what they look at. This private film is exactly what is seems to be: the never-before-seen denouncer of invisible and sensual relationships.”

results.title: Rapt
results.brief_description:
A virtual body built from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans of the artist’s body. MRI scans map the water content of the body to produce axial slices. These scans were used to create a 3D body accessible on any plane, making it possible to navigate through the body, and to view it internally and externally.

(Special thanks to Ray Scan Imaging and The Childrens’ Hospital Westmead Sydney)

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Kathy Drayton, Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Jackie Farkas uses the extraordinary and harrowing oral testimony of an elderly Hungarian woman as the basis for a poetic and abstract investigation into how cinema can ‘illustrate’ such profoundly horrendous experiences. The use of found footage, elusive images of beauty and horror and sequences from ‘The Wizard of Oz’ to elucidate the narrator’s memories creates an extraordinary representation of the holocaust experience, of survival, of home and memory, and of how we can comprehend the incomprehensible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kathy Drayton, Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: The Way things go
results.creator_credit: Mirjam Krakenberger, Rainer Trinkler, Peter Fischli and David Weiss
results.brief_description: Inside a warehouse, artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss build an enormous, precarious structure 100 feet long made out of common household items - tea kettles, tires, old shoes, balloons, wooden ramps, etc. Then, with fire, water, gravity, and chemistry, they create a spectacular chain reaction, a self destructing performance of physical interactions, chemical reactions, and precisely-crafted chaos worthy of Rube Goldberg or Alfred Hitchcock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mirjam Krakenberger, Rainer Trinkler, Peter Fischli and David Weiss
